verses.verse: (1 The withered hand is healed.6 The Pharisees consult with the Herodians.10 Many are healed by touching Christ.11 At his sight the devils fall down before him.14 The twelve Apostles.24 The kingdom divided against itself.29 Blasphemy against the holy Ghost.33 Christ’s parents.) And he entered again into the Synagogue, and there was a man which had a (That is, unprofitable and dead.) withered hand.
And they watched him, whether he would heal him on the Sabbath day, that they might accuse him.
Then he said unto the man which had the withered hand, Arise: stand forth in the midst.

And he said to them, Is it lawful to do a good deed on the Sabbath day, or to do evil? to save the (A figurative speech, by the figure Synecdoche. For this kind of saying, To save the life, is as much, as to save the man.) life, or to kill? but they held their peace.

Then he looked round about on them (Men, when they have wrong done unto them, are angry, but not without vice, but Christ is angry without vice, neither is he sorry so much for the injury that is done to his own person, as for their wickedness: and therefore he had pity upon them, and for that cause is he said to have mourned.) angrily, mourning also for the (As though their heart had been so closed up, and grown together, that wholesome doctrine could prevail no more with them.) hardness of their hearts, and said to the man, Stretch forth thine hand. And he stretched it out: and his hand was restored, as whole as the other.

¶ (The more the truth is kept under, the more it cometh out.) And the Pharisees departed, and straightway gathered a council with the (See also Matt. 22:16.) Herodians against him, that they might destroy him.
But Jesus avoided with his disciples to the sea: and a great multitude followed him from Galilee, and from Judea,

And from Jerusalem, and from Idumea, and (Which Josephus calleth stony or rocky.) beyond Jordan: and they that dwelled about Tyre and Sidon, when they had heard what great things he did, came unto him in great number.
And he commanded his disciples, that a little ship should (Should always be ready for him.) wait for him, because of the multitude, lest they should throng him.
For he had healed many, insomuch that they pressed upon him to touch him, as many as had (Diseases wherewith God scourgeth men as it were with whips.) plagues.

And when the (In them whom they had entered into: or by the figure called Metonymy, for them which were vexed with unclean spirits.) unclean spirits saw him, they fell down before him, and cried, saying, Thou art the Son of God.
And he sharply rebuked them, to the end they should not utter him.
¶ (Mark 6:7; Matt. 10:1; Luke 9:1) Then he went up into a mountain, and called unto him whom he would, and they came unto him.

(The twelve Apostles are set apart to be trained up to the office of the Apostleship.) And he (Chose and appointed out twelve to be familiar and conversant with him.) appointed twelve, that they should be with him, and that he might send them to preach.
And that they might have power to heal sicknesses, and to cast out devils:
And the first was Simon, and he named Simon, Peter,
Then James the son of Zebedee, and John James’ brother (and surnamed them Boanerges, which is, The sons of thunder.)

And Andrew, and Philip, and Bartholomew, and Matthew, and Thomas, and James the son of Alphaeus, and (Whom Luke also calleth Judas: and for difference’s sake, the other Judas is called Iscariot.) Thaddaeus, and Simon the Canaanite,
And Judas Iscariot, who also betrayed him, and they came (The disciples whom Christ had taken to be of his train and to live with him, come home to his house, to be with him always after.) home.
And the multitude assembled again, so that they could not so much as eat bread.

(None are worse enemies of the Gospel, than they that least ought.) And when his (Word for word, they that were of him, that is, his kinfolks: for they that were mad, were brought to their kinsmen.) kinsfolks heard of it, they went out to lay hold on him: for they said that he was beside himself.
¶ (Matt. 9:34; Matt. 12:24; Luke 11:15) And the Scribes which came down from Jerusalem, said, He hath Beelzebub, and through the prince of the devils he casteth out devils.
But he called them unto him, and said unto them in parables, How can Satan drive out Satan?
For if a kingdom be divided against itself, that kingdom cannot stand.
Or if a house be divided against itself, that house cannot continue.
So if (Satan’s imps or . . . .) Satan make insurrection against himself, and be divided, he cannot endure, but is at an end.
No man can enter into a strong man’s house, and take away his goods, except he first bind that strong man, and then spoil his house.

¶ Verily I say unto you, all sins shall be forgiven unto the children of men, and blasphemies, wherewith they blaspheme: (They only are without hope of salvation, which do maliciously oppugn Christ, whom they know.) (Matt. 18:31; Luke 12:10; John 5:16)
But he that blasphemeth against the holy Ghost, shall never have forgiveness, but is culpable of eternal damnation.
(These are the words of the Evangelist.) Because they said, He had an unclean spirit.

¶ (Matt. 12:46; Luke 8:19) Then came his (Under this name Brother, the Hebrews understand all that are of the same stock and kindred.) brethren and mother and stood without, and sent unto him, and called him.
And the people sat about him, and they said unto him, Behold, thy mother, and thy brethren seek for thee without.
But he answered them, saying, Who is my mother and my brethren?
(The spiritual kindred is far otherwise to be accounted of, than the carnal or fleshly.) And he looked round about on them, which sat in compass about him, and said, Behold my mother and my brethren.
For whosoever doeth the will of God, he is my brother, my sister, and my mother.
